Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: AI Robotics-driven Material Discovery Platform
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to accelerate the development of new high-performance battery materials with an Artificial Intelligence (AI) robotics-driven material development platform. The platform uses machine learning and robotic high-throughput automation to accelerate effective experiment planning and minimize errors. It will potentially have a substantial positive impact on the commercialization of superior battery materials (projected to be a $14 B market by 2025), to support growth of electric vehicles and other sustainable transportation.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to build a material development platform featuring a closed-loop machine learning and robotic high-throughput automation, and to develop a high-performance polymer electrolyte product for lithium batteries. The platform can potentially change how material innovation is performed and enable accelerated discovery of electrolytes and other battery materials. The platformâ€™s workflow iterates the following: (1) initial electrolyte knowledge base collection; (2) machine-learning model training using the knowledge base; (3) new electrolyte prescription by the model; (4) parallelized experimental validation via high-throughput equipment; and (5) knowledge base updates. Phase I will help to (1) build key electrochemical and mechanical modules on the robotic system for electrolyte development, (2) improve machine learning models in terms of feasibility, flexibility, and the capability of optimizing multiple objective functions, and (3) develop the polymer electrolyte formulation in order to improve its three primary properties, including ionic conductivity, voltage stability, and mechanical modulus. It is anticipated that the platform will achieve high productivity and effectiveness, significantly improve electrolyte properties, and identify an electrolyte that meets commercialization system requirements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Discovering new materials is crucial in developing modern technologies and ultimately enhances society's well-being. Because of its enormous space of parameters, new material discovery by using the traditional trial-and-error method, is usually expensive and labor-intensive, taking an average of 10 to 20 years to complete. For example, the lithium-Ion battery was initially proposed in 1970[1], and it took more than 20 years to develop its suitable battery materials and corresponding technology before Sony and Asahi Kasei made the first commercial lithium-ion battery product [2]. Nearly half a century later, the material is still a fundamental bottleneck in the battery industry.

From the 1980s to 1990s, automation and robotics development resulted in the quick adoption of high throughput technology in the pharmaceutical industry and, eventually, in material discovery. Rapid formulation, synthesis, and property screening with automation and parallel technology helped speed up the drug and material discovery processes [3][4]. The recent technological developments regarding artificial intelligence and machine learning opened a new door for material R&D [5]. The combination of AI with robotics may potentially revolutionize the material discovery process and dramatically reduce the time to market for new materials [6][7].

With the support of the NSF SBIR Phase I project, we have successfully developed an AI-Robotic closed-loop platform called MARS (Materials AI-Robotic System) and applied the platform to polymer electrolyte materials discovery.

Our AI-Robotic workflow includes the following closed-loop components: (1) An established knowledge database created with existing experiments? data from the literature, public databases, as well as in-house experimental results. (2) Machine learning algorithms that search through the database based on the scope created by scientists and generate promising new recipes. (3) Robotic stations that formulate the recipes generated by AI. (4) High-throughput stations that process and test samples generated by robotic formulations. (5) Automatic data processing that processes data results and feeds them back to the database for a new round of AI search and recipe generation.

We have demonstrated that the AI-Robotic approach is faster and more effective for polymer electrolyte material discovery and optimization. Some major achievements of the project include:

(1)   Developed a closed-loop AI Robotic platform for battery materials discovery including AI algorithms and data processing software, hardware such as electrochemical stations, and a database. One patent was filed.

(2)   Machine learning development yielded a high prediction correlation of 0.92 (Pearson coefficient) and predicted electrolytes with two orders of magnitude higher ionic conductivity than the best in the pool.

(3)   Achieved experiment throughput of 128 samples/day with our MARS platform, and explored and exploited a search space of 118 chemical ingredients. 64,180 predicted electrolytes and 8,192 lab datapoints were generated for polymer electrolyte material discovery.

(4)   Established a database with a vast amount of data generated through in-house experiments and literature traversal. This technical asset provides the foundation for innovating new polymer electrolyte material.

(5)   Discovered polymer electrolytes with a significant improvement in performance. An ionic conductivity of 1.4 x 10-2 S/cm was achieved at the room temperature, which was six orders of magnitude higher than the baseline. Catholyte polymer electrolytes and separator polymer electrolytes showed promising properties.

(6)   Executed a joint development project with a top automobile company for its special synthesis formulation and testing requirements, achieving a higher throughput 10 times better than what they are doing in their own lab.

We plan to further develop the platform to a more autonomous platform by adapting multi axis robot for plates transfer between stations, as well as integrating all the data into one centralized database, and apply the platform on the high-performance polymer electrolyte materials discovery and optimization.

We believe the AI-Robotic platform is a breakthrough methodology promising to greatly reduce the need for human involvement compared to traditional lab R&D experiments. It is likely to radically shift the settings of facilities, laboratories, and instruments from the conventional scientist-centric layout to a machine-centric layout. It also has the potential to serve broad energy material areas such as new functional materials, catalysis, semiconductor, consumer application, and information technologies.

[1] Whittingham, M. S. (1976). "Electrical Energy Storage and Intercalation Chemistry". Science. 192 (4244): 1126?1127

[2] "Keywords to understanding Sony Energy Devices - keyword 1991". Archived from the original on 4 March 2016.

[3] "Accelerating R&D, Symyx is applying tools developed for the drug industry to research into new materials". C&EN, Volume 83, Issue 38, September 19, 2005

[4] "Quantitative High-Throughput Screening (qHTS): A Titration-based Approach that Efficiently Identifies Biological Activities in Large Chemical Libraries". Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 103 (31): 11473 - 11478. 

[5]" Recent advances and applications of machine learning in solid-state materials science ". npj Computational Materials volume 5, Article number: 83 (2019) 

[6]" A mobile robotic chemist ", Nature volume 583, pages237 - 241(2020)

[7]" Machine Learning in Materials informatics - Methods and Applications" ACS Meeting Presentation, 2021.
